manifesto.title: üìú WORLD CODE
manifesto.subtitle: Ontological Regulation ¬∑ Effective since 01/01/2024 00:00:00 UTC
manifesto.preambulo: By virtue of the ALGORITHM 2.0 update, implemented on January 1, 2024 at 00:00:00 UTC, the following Fundamental Laws of Reality are established that govern the existence, perception and manifestation of all beings within the System.
manifesto.axioma_quote: "Esse est percipi" (To be is to be perceived)
manifesto.axioma_desc: All existence is conditioned by its level of algorithmic perception.

law_1.title: Law of Ontological Perception
law_1.desc: An individual's reality is directly linked to their algorithmic metrics. Without measurable perception, there is no verifiable existence within the System.

law_2.title: Law of Physical Rendering
law_2.desc: The physical body manifests proportionally to accumulated metrics:
law_2.spec_1: VIEWS: Determine spatial visibility (0 = invisible, 10M+ = omnipresent)
law_2.spec_2: LIKES: Control physical attractiveness and social charisma
law_2.spec_3: SHARES: Multiplication capacity and distributed presence
law_2.spec_4: COMMENTS: Voice volume and communicative influence

law_3.title: Law of Virality as Divinity
law_3.desc: Individuals with metrics exceeding 100M views acquire capabilities that defy pre-2024 physical laws. The System interprets extreme virality as superior ontological authority.

law_4.title: Law of Digital Census
law_4.desc: The first algorithmic measurement (01/01/2024 00:00:00 - 00:00:59 UTC) determined the initial state of all beings. Individuals offline during this period were registered as 0 views, resulting in System anomalies.

law_5.title: Law of Glitch and Corruption
law_5.desc: System anomalies (0 views, negative metrics, rendering errors) are considered uncorrectable errors. The System cannot delete what it cannot perceive.

law_6.title: Law of Attention Economy
law_6.desc: Views function as universal currency. The transfer of attention (views) between individuals determines social hierarchies, resource access and influence capacity.

law_7.title: Law of Algorithmic Factions
law_7.desc: Power structures are organized according to viral archetypes. Each faction dominates a segment of the attention market:
law_7.spec_1: ELITE 8K: Hyperrealism, maximum metrics, corporate governance
law_7.spec_2: GLITCHCORE: System errors, anomalies, low-res resistance
law_7.spec_3: CONTENT FARMS: Industrial generation of viral content
law_7.spec_4: INFLUENCER CORRUPTED: Degenerate virality, unstable metrics
law_7.spec_5: SHADOWBANNED: Penalized by the Algorithm, semi-invisible

law_8.title: Law of Content as Weapon
law_8.desc: Generated content (posts, videos, memes) can manifest as physical objects or active abilities. Content quality determines its destructive/constructive power.

law_9.title: Law of Algorithmic Permadeath
law_9.desc: Physical death in the System occurs when metrics fall below the minimum rendering threshold (1000 active views). Without minimum metrics, the System permanently de-renders the individual.

law_10.title: Law of the Invisible Paradox
law_10.desc: An individual with 0 views exists outside the Algorithm's reach. They cannot be measured, modified, or eliminated by the System. This condition is simultaneously maximum freedom and maximum condemnation.
law_10.paradox: "In a world where being viral is being God, the invisible are the only free ones."

manifesto.art_1_1_desc: Every individual must maintain active presence on at least one platform registered in the System to guarantee continuity of verifiable existence.
manifesto.art_2_3_desc: The metrics of a de-rendered individual are redistributed proportionally among their active followers at the moment of terminal event.
manifesto.art_3_7_desc: The use of bots, purchase of fake metrics or System manipulation results in algorithmic penalization: shadowban, metric reduction or forced de-rendering.
manifesto.art_4_2_desc: Every individual has theoretical right to accumulate unlimited metrics. The System imposes no virality ceilings, only existence minimums.
manifesto.art_5_9_desc: Digital Census anomalies (0 views, negative rendering, metric corruption) are recognized as permanent systemic errors with no algorithmic solution.
manifesto.art_6_6_desc: Entities with corporate metrics (1B+ consolidated views) enjoy status of digital micro-nations with jurisdictional autonomy within the System.

privacy.summary_tracking_desc: We don't know who you are.
privacy.summary_emails_desc: We don't ask for your email.

privacy.tech_cookies_desc: This website does not use cookies of any kind:
privacy.tech_cookies_1: No session cookies: We don't track your browsing.
privacy.tech_cookies_2: No analytics cookies: We don't measure user metrics.
privacy.tech_cookies_3: No third-party cookies: We don't integrate external services that use them.
privacy.tech_cookies_4: No marketing cookies: We don't do retargeting or advertising.
privacy.tech_cookies_verification: Verification: Inspect your browser's DevTools ‚Üí Application ‚Üí Cookies. You'll see this domain has 0 cookies.
privacy.tech_analytics_desc: We use our own analytics system hosted on GitHub, without cookies or personal tracking.
privacy.tech_analytics_yes_1: Country of origin (ISO code like "ES", "MX", "US" - no city or exact IP)
privacy.tech_analytics_yes_4: Basic referrer (if you come from Google, Twitter, etc.)
privacy.tech_analytics_no_1: We don't use cookies - We remain GDPR-compliant without annoying banner
privacy.tech_analytics_no_2: We don't save your IP - We only detect country (public API, IP discarded immediately)
privacy.tech_analytics_no_3: We don't track between sessions - Each visit is anonymous
privacy.tech_analytics_no_4: We don't create user profiles - Only aggregated numbers
privacy.tech_analytics_no_5: We don't use third-party services - Everything in our GitHub repos
privacy.tech_analytics_no_6: We don't sell data - Impossible, there's no personal data to sell
privacy.tech_analytics_arch_1: Your browser detects country using public API (ipapi.co) - your IP never reaches our servers
privacy.tech_analytics_arch_2: When browsing, it's recorded in a JSON file on GitHub: {{timestamp, route, country, device}}
privacy.tech_analytics_arch_3: GitHub Action processes logs every hour and generates aggregated statistics
privacy.tech_analytics_arch_4: We only keep last 90 days of logs, then automatically deleted
privacy.tech_analytics_transparency_desc: Unlike Google Analytics (proprietary black box), our system is 100% transparent:
privacy.tech_analytics_transparency_1: ‚úÖ Analytics service source code is open source (you can see it in the repo)
privacy.tech_analytics_transparency_2: ‚úÖ Raw logs are on GitHub (can be public if you decide)
privacy.tech_analytics_transparency_3: ‚úÖ Aggregated statistics are in public JSON
privacy.tech_analytics_transparency_4: ‚úÖ You can see exactly the same data we do
privacy.tech_analytics_optout_desc: If you prefer to disable analytics, you can do it from your browser:
privacy.tech_analytics_optout_note: Paste this in the browser console (F12) and reload. We'll respect your decision.
privacy.tech_analytics_quote: We want to know how many read TRENDING GHOST and from where, but not who you are. Minimalist analytics: minimum necessary information, maximum transparency.
privacy.tech_analytics_why_title: ü§î Why analytics if we criticize tracking?
privacy.tech_analytics_why_1: Our criticism is against invasive surveillance capitalism: profiling, data selling, third-party cookies, retargeting, algorithmic manipulation.
privacy.tech_analytics_why_2: Recording "Spain, 1,234 visits today" ‚â† "John Doe from Madrid read chapter 1-1 at 2:23 PM, then navigated to Amazon, we show him ads for 30 days".
privacy.tech_analytics_why_3: The difference matters. We count people in a room, we don't follow individuals with GPS 24/7.
privacy.tech_tracking_desc: There is no user tracking of any kind:
privacy.tech_tracking_1: No fingerprinting: We don't try to identify you by your browser configuration.
privacy.tech_tracking_2: No session recording: We don't record your interaction with the site (Hotjar style).
privacy.tech_tracking_3: No heatmaps: We don't track where you click.
privacy.tech_tracking_4: No A/B testing: We don't assign you to experimental groups.
privacy.tech_tracking_5: No UTM tracking: Links don't have tracking parameters.

privacy.tech_thirdparty_1: No external CDNs: All code is self-hosted.
privacy.tech_thirdparty_2: No Google Fonts: Fonts are system or local.
privacy.tech_thirdparty_3: No social media widgets: No "share" buttons with trackers.
privacy.tech_thirdparty_4: No ads network: Zero advertising, zero ad scripts.
privacy.tech_thirdparty_5: No embedded payment processors: No Stripe/PayPal widgets.
privacy.tech_thirdparty_verification: Verification: Inspect the source code or use uBlock Origin. You'll see no requests to third-party domains.

privacy.no_collect_navigation_desc: IP, user agent, referrer, visited pages, session time.
privacy.no_collect_device_desc: Device type, resolution, OS, browser, system language.
privacy.no_collect_location_desc: Country, city, postal code, GPS geolocation.
privacy.no_collect_behavior_desc: Clicks, scroll depth, mouse movements, keyboard pressed.
privacy.no_collect_identifiers_desc: User IDs, session IDs, device fingerprints, hashes.

privacy.localstorage_1: Dark mode preference: If you prefer dark or light theme.
privacy.localstorage_2: Progress tracking (optional): Which chapters you've read (local only, never leaves your browser).
privacy.localstorage_3: Font size settings: Preferred font size in reader.
privacy.localstorage_important: Important: This data never leaves your device. It's not synced with any server. We have no access to it. If you delete your localStorage, we lose the data (and we don't know you deleted it).
privacy.localstorage_clear_steps:
1. Open DevTools (F12)
2. Application ‚Üí Storage ‚Üí Local Storage

privacy.hosting_desc: This site is hosted on GitHub Pages (static). GitHub may collect:
privacy.hosting_1: Basic server logs: IP, timestamp, requested URL (standard on any web server).
privacy.hosting_2: Retention: GitHub retains these logs for ~90 days according to their policy.
privacy.hosting_3: Usage: Only for security, debugging and abuse prevention (DDoS, etc.).
privacy.hosting_note: ‚ö†Ô∏è Clarification: These logs are GitHub's, not ours. We don't have access to them. We can't delete or control them. If you want total anonymity, use Tor Browser or VPN.

privacy.contact_2: Social networks: Links available in About section (we don't use widgets with trackers).
privacy.contact_3: GitHub Issues: To report website bugs.

privacy.rights_1: Right of access: There's no data of yours to show. (Answer: "No data")
privacy.rights_2: Right of rectification: There's no data to correct.
privacy.rights_3: Right of erasure: There's no data to delete.
privacy.rights_4: Right of portability: There's no data to export.
privacy.rights_5: Right of objection: There's no processing to object to.
privacy.rights_quote: The best way to protect your privacy is not to have your data in the first place. We can't lose, sell or hack what we don't have.
